A **helmet** is a type of [helm](/wiki/Helm "Helm") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") and has a [randomized appearance](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance"); the default one associated with it is a [plumed helmet](/wiki/Plumed_helmet "Plumed helmet").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) It appears as a **kabuto** for [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai").

## Generation

[Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") start each game with a +0 helmet.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) All other martial roles - [Barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), [Monks](/wiki/Monk "Monk"), [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai"), and [Valkyries](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie") - begin the game with knowledge of its randomized appearance.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

Any [elven](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)"), [orcish](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)") or [dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") player character that would start the game with a helmet will start with an appropriate [racial helm](/wiki/Racial_equipment "Racial equipment") instead, though there are no applicable roles where this substitution occurs.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

In addition to random generation, general [stores](/wiki/Store "Store") and used armor dealerships can sell helmets.

[Mercenaries](/wiki/Mercenaries "Mercenaries") have a 2⁄3 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") helmets.[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)

## Description

When worn, a helmet grants 1 base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") plus any additional properties from its randomized appearance. As a metallic helm, it hinders [spellcasting](/wiki/Spellcasting "Spellcasting"), but also protects from most damage inflicted by falling objects, such as a read [scroll of earth](/wiki/Scroll_of_earth "Scroll of earth") or a triggered [falling rock trap](/wiki/Falling_rock_trap "Falling rock trap").

## Strategy

Standard helmets are the most unremarkable of the randomized helms: they are sufficient as a basic source of AC and head protection, but players will often encounter the almost-identical [orcish helm](/wiki/Orcish_helm "Orcish helm") or the lighter [dented pot](/wiki/Dented_pot "Dented pot") first before they see a regular helmet. It may still provide a viable replacement for an existing helm if it is generated with a positive enchantment and/or has the appearance of a visored helmet, which offers eye protection.

Like most early helms, helmets are usually replaced by an [elven leather helm](/wiki/Elven_leather_helm "Elven leather helm") or any of the other randomized helms due to the additional perks they offer - even a [dwarvish iron helm](/wiki/Dwarvish_iron_helm "Dwarvish iron helm") is a suitable substitute due to offering more base AC.

### Identification

Helmets can easily be distinguished from other randomized helms by price and weight: they are the only ones to have a base cost of 10 [zm](/wiki/Zm "Zm"), making [price identification](/wiki/Price_identification "Price identification") in a shop trivial even without buying or selling one. Helmets also weigh 30 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum"), while the other randomized helms weigh 50.

## History

The helmet first appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

## Variants

In variants where item weight is shown, helmets are somewhat easier to identify.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [Undead Slayers](/wiki/Undead_Slayer "Undead Slayer") can start the game with a +0 helmet unless they are elves or orcs, who will start with the appropriate racial helm in those cases.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), a [helm of telepathy](/wiki/Helm_of_telepathy "Helm of telepathy") can be created at a [furnace](/wiki/Furnace "Furnace") by combining a plain helmet and an [amulet of ESP](/wiki/Amulet_of_ESP "Amulet of ESP").

### notdNetHack

[notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") adds [The Crown of Berith](/wiki/The_Crown_of_Berith "The Crown of Berith"), a [golden](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") artifact helmet than protects against brain-sucking attacks while worn and can be safely enchanted to +7. [Berith](/wiki/Berith "Berith") himself is generated with this helm when summoned by an [Illithanachronounbinder](/wiki/Illithanachronounbinder "Illithanachronounbinder").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), [giant](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)") Barbarians and [Cavemen](/wiki/Cavemen "Cavemen") receive a helmet in place of the role's standard armor.

[Flinds](/wiki/Flind_\(EvilHack\) "Flind (EvilHack)") have a 1⁄4 chance of generating with a helmet, and [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") have a 1⁄4 chance of generating with a helmet; [Croesus](/wiki/Croesus "Croesus") has a 1⁄2 chance of generating with a [golden](/wiki/Gold_\(material\) "Gold (material)") helmet, and [Kas](/wiki/Kas "Kas") is always generated with a helmet. Mercenaries will often generate with helmets unless they are [drow](/wiki/Drow_\(monster_attribute\) "Drow (monster attribute)"), [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)") or [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_attribute\) "Orc (monster attribute)"), and the helmet also appears in the kits of various [player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster_\(EvilHack\) "Player monster (EvilHack)"), particularly lower-level ones.

A helmet can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a dented pot and a [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger"). Helmets can be used to forge several items:

- A helmet can be combined with a dagger to create a [small shield](/wiki/Small_shield "Small shield").
- Two helmets can be combined to create a [large shield](/wiki/Large_shield "Large shield").
- A helmet can be combined with a large shield to create [ring mail](/wiki/Ring_mail "Ring mail").
- A helmet can be combined with ring mail to create [scale mail](/wiki/Scale_mail "Scale mail").
- A helmet can be combined with a [dwarvish short sword](/wiki/Dwarvish_short_sword "Dwarvish short sword") to create a [dwarvish helm](/wiki/Dwarvish_helm "Dwarvish helm").
- A helmet can be combined with a [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace") to create a pair of [gauntlets](/wiki/Gauntlets_\(EvilHack\) "Gauntlets (EvilHack)").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, [Paladins](/wiki/Paladin_\(role\) "Paladin (role)") start the game with a helmet unless they are elves or dwarves, who will start with the appropriate racial helm in those cases.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), [tortle](/wiki/Tortle_\(starting_race\) "Tortle (starting race)") Undead Slayers receive a [toque](/wiki/Toque "Toque") in place of the standard helmet.

[Padawans](/wiki/Padawan "Padawan") and [Jedi trainers](/index.php?title=Jedi_trainers\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Jedi trainers (page does not exist)") have a 1⁄4 chance of generating with a helmet. All details from SLASH'EM and EvilHack are applicable.

## Encyclopedia entry

### Kabuto

The kabuto is the helmet worn by the samurai. It was characterized by a prominent beaked front which jutted out over the brow to protect the wearer's face; a feature that gives rise to their modern Japanese name of 'shokaku tsuki kabuto' (battering-ram helmet). Their main constructional element was an oval plate, the shokaku bo, slightly domed for the head with a narrow prolongation in front that curved forwards and downwards where it developed a pronounced central fold. Two horizontal strips encircling the head were riveted to this frontal strip: the lower one, the koshimaki (hip wrap), formed the lower edge of the helmet bowl; the other, the do maki (body wrap), was set at about the level of the temples. Filling the gaps between these strips and the shokaku bo were small plates, sometimes triangular but more commonly rectangular in shape. Because the front projected so far from the head, the triangular gap beneath was filled by a small plate, the shoshaku tei ita, whose rear edge bent downwards into a flange that rested against the forehead.

\[ Arms & Armor of the Samurai, by Bottomley & Hopson ]

It may still provide a viable replacement for an existing helm if it is generated with a positive enchantment and/or has the appearance of a visored helmet, which offers eye protection.

Like most early helms, helmets are usually replaced by an elven leather helm or any of the other randomized helms due to the additional perks they offer - even a dwarvish iron helm is a suitable substitute due to offering more base AC.

The helmet first appears in Hack 1.0.

Variants

In variants where item weight is shown, helmets are somewhat easier to identify.

SLASH'EM

SpliceHack

[[Padawan]]s and [[Jedi trainers]] have a {{frac|4}} chance of generating with a helmet. All details from SLASH'EM and EvilHack are applicable.

==Encyclopedia entry==
===Kabuto===
{{encyclopedia|
The kabuto is the helmet worn by the samurai.  It was characterized by a prominent beaked front which jutted out over the brow to protect the wearer's face; a feature that gives rise to their modern Japanese name of 'shokaku tsuki kabuto' (battering-ram helmet).  Their main constructional element was an oval plate, the shokaku bo, slightly domed for the head with a narrow prolongation in front that curved forwards and downwards where it developed a pronounced central fold.  Two horizontal strips encircling the head were riveted to this frontal strip:  the lower one, the koshimaki (hip wrap), formed the lower edge of the helmet bowl; the other, the do maki (body wrap), was set at about the level of the temples.  Filling the gaps between these strips and the shokaku bo were small plates, sometimes triangular but more commonly rectangular in shape.  Because the front projected so far from the head, the triangular gap beneath was filled by a small plate, the shoshaku tei ita, whose rear edge bent downwards into a flange that rested against the forehead.
|[ Arms & Armor of the Samurai, by Bottomley & Hopson ]
